div.head: THE MOSLEM MENACE.
div.p: In an interesting article in the September “Nineteenth Centnry" Captain H. A. Wilson discusses under the title "The Moslem Menace" the probable effects of the secret propagandist organisation conducted in Africa by the Mohammedan sect known as Senussia. The primary object of the sect is to free Moslem countries from the rule of the infidel, end this is to be accomplished by a universal Jehad or Holy War. "At the present moment over all the British possessions on the East and West coasts of Africa, and of course in Egypt and the

Sudan, the most determined efforts are being made to enlist into membership all the Mo-hammedan troops. Since the west coast is far more in touch with the north by the several caravan routes it is natural that Senassia preaching has been in progress longer and has taken a deeper root there than on the East. I believe that I am absolutely correct in saying that numbers of Senussia agents yearly enlist as soldiers with the sole purpose of carrying on their mission among the troops."

Captain Wilson, having referred to the diffi-culty of obtaining credible information owing to the secrecy of the movement gives the fol-lowing story obtained from ex-Dervish prisoners at Atbara and Omdurman : "The Sheikh Senussi is at present at Tunis Khuddera en-gaged in organising a movement for a general Mohammedan rising throughout Africa. He has agents throughout North and West Africa, and his agents have reached East Africa, and are enlisting the Mohammedans there in the cause. Also the Sheikh Senossi's intention, before starting a general rising, is to get his movement thoroughly organised, and then if possible, to wait until a war breaks out in which either France, or England, or both are involved, and are thus unable to give a great deal of attention to Africa.” The writer adds : "Another significant and interesting point is that I have reliable information that yearly numbers of the Senussia are sent to Europe, chiefly to England and France, to be thoroughly educated on European lines. These men come chiefly from the North and West of Africa. These two facts alone show definitely that we are dealing with no ordinary Arab or Negro fanatical outbreak, but with a vast organised movement directed by a high intelligence whose ramifications extend everywhere, and which in the coming years will prove itself a distinct and important, if not the dominating, factor in the affairs of the Dark Continent."

Concluding his article Captain Wilson writes: "Most probably I shall be set down as an alarmist, but it is my absolute and certain conviction that the Senussia is a far more mighty force than we in Europe have any conception of, that it is prospering and gaining prestige daily—almost hourly—and that the day is drawing steadily nearer when we shall stand face fo face with a wave of Mohammedan fanaticism, universal throughout the Continent, thorougly organised and amply prepared, compared to which all previons wars with blaok racos will the merest child's play. This may not come in our time, for the able heads that direct are taking no risks, and mean when war does come to have all things ready and the odds as far as possible in their favour. I think, myself, that the next twenty years will see the advent of the crisis, but who can be certain ?—it may be fifty years hence, it may be to-morrow. It is needless to mention the effect that a Mohammedan rising of this magnitude will have on the warlike. Pagan races of Africa such as the Zulus, Swazis, Basutos, Wanyema, Masai, &c., who will jump at the chance of striking a blow at their white masters. I am convinced that when the time does come every black skin in Africa. with the possible exception of the Christian Abyssinians, will be in arms against the white races. When that day does come, and come it will certain as fate, the whites in Africa will be at death grips with one of the most formidable 'movements of all time—& wave of Moslem fanaticism rolling in countless numbers across the African continent. Composed of some of the very finest fighting material — if not the very finest — in the whole world, much of it trained to arms by Europeans, well armed, ably organised and led, gathering momentum at every step, there will spring into being one of the most irresistible forces the world will yet have seen. In a day there will have arisen a situation compar-ed to which the Indian Mutiny and the Sudan campaigns combined would be the smallest of incidents. As I have already said, this will probably be considered an absurdly exaggerated view. Let me once again reiterate my firm conviction that the next twenty years will see Europe struggling in the forces of an African war against forces so great that at the end it is unlikely to a degree that a single white man remains in Africa."

div.head: Local Mouled.
div.p: The Sidi-Gaber mouled has been authorised to commence from the 21st inst.

div.head: Police Budget.
div.p: 7 thefts, 14 misdemeanours and 43 minor offences came under the notice of the Cairo police during the course of yesterday.

div.head: White Slave Traffic.
div.p: The French consulate have decided to take steps to expel from the country five French subjects guilty of white slave trafficing.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and C.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half past four this afternoon.

div.head: Cotton Worm.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has struck off 68 names from the staff list of employés enga-ged on Cotton Worm work whose services are no longer required.

div.head: Suspected Abduction.
div.p: A young Greek girl, aged 14, named Aglaia Magaotaki, who was living with her parents in Sharia Clot Bey, has been missing for the past two days. A search party has been organised.

div.head: A Voluntary Surrender.
div.p: Michel Guidicile, the Italian hair-dresser who committed the savage assault reported in our columns yesterday has given himself over to the Italian consulate and has been sent to the Menshieh prison.

div.head: The Price of Coal.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes Company requests us to inform our readers that owing to the rise in the price of coal the passage rates between Alexandria and Marseilles will be increased by 10 % from the 15th inst. until further notice.

div.head: Rains in the Sudan.
div.p: The War Ministry has received a telegram from the Sudan stating that the line of communication between Khartoum and Shendi has been temporarily interrupted, owing to a washout caused by recent heavy rains and advising passengers to defer their departure.

div.head: Bibby Line.
div.p: Our readers will be interested to know that the general increase in the passage rates will not affect the Bibby Line, whose fares will reinain as hitherto £12 hence to Marseilles and £17 to London. The reduced summer rates will expire at the end of this month.

div.head: Plague Aboard Ship.
div.p: The Anchor liner "Circassia” which arrived at Suez on Monday night from Bombay, landed a suspected case of bubonic plague, which was conveyed to Moses Wells for treatment ; the steamer after being disinfected by the quaran-tine authorities, entered the Canal this forenoon in strict quarantine.

div.head: Raids.
div.p: The special police brigade made a raid on two hashish smoking dens during Monday night last; in Sharia Zahar, where an Italian, named Natali, and a native named Mohamed Fadi, were arrested. 25 berberines were also arrested by the special police brigade in Tewfekia, Ismailia and Marouf quariers of Cairo during the same evening as they were unable to prove any visible means of sustenance.

div.head: Plague
div.p: During the week ending the 9th September, six cases of bubonic plague were registered throughout Egypt, all of which occurred at Alexandria. From the beginning of the year to the 9th instant 1028 cases of plague were recorded in Egypt as against 446 registered during the corresponding period of last year. 1 case at Alexandria was the only fresh case of plague reported during the past 24 hours. 5 patients are still under treatment.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS

Le 10 Septembre 1907 de 9 h. a.m. à 1 h. p.m. la Municipalité procèdera à la vente aux enchères publiques près du Fort (Port Rosette) d'one quantité de 10000 m3 environ de pierres provenant de la dite démolition, ainsi que d'une quantité de fenêtres, vieux bois.
Les pierres sont divisées en lots de 2 à 100 m3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en-chère de 1% et déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudica-tion. ;

Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de Dix (10) jours sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et sous perte du dépôt de 10%.
La Municipalité est libre de ne pas donner suite à l'adjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts.
Alexandrie, le 4 Septembre 1907.
Le Vice Président, (Signé) DR. SCHIESS. 30874-3-1

div.head: SLATIN PASHA HONOURED.
div.p: LONDON, Wednesday.
Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha has been granted the honorary rank of Major-General in the British Army, dating from to-day.

div.head: DATE OF RETURN.
div.p: The Khedive bas addressed the following letter to Fakhry Pasha, Regent, from Constantinople, dated the 6th inst. :—

"I arrived here on the 3rd inst. and will start for Egypt on the 1st October. I have read your reports with interest and am glad to observe that no adverse incident has occur-red this sommer, with the exception of the financial crisis, which, I trust, is nearly at an end. The bad state of the Nile food greatly disappoints me, but I note with pleasure the measures taken by the irrigation service to ensure good crops. I trust that the rise of the Nile will continue and that no harm will result to the country.”

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers, which will meet to-morrow under the presidency of Fakhry Pasha will consider,
(1) Proposed appointments and transfers in the Postal Administration.
(2) Proposet credit of L.E. 13,000 for the purposes of irrigation, to be devoted to Upper Egypt.
(3) That Saad Pasha Zagloul should temporarily act for Ahmed Mazloum Pasha, and Ibrahim Pasha Fouad for Abani Pasha, as Ministers of Finance and War respectively.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
div.p: Saad Zagloul Pasha has addressed the following telegram to Moheb Pasha, Governor of the Suez Canal :—

"Please say good-bye on my behalf to the Egyptian students leaving to-day (Tuesday) for England to graduate, and express my regret at being unable to do so personally. I trust that they will make every endeavour to obtain the success which I desire them for the good of their country.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à 11h. 1/2 a.m.).

La tenue d'aujourd'hni que nous attendions pour juger de la tendance a été franchement mauvaise. Plus faibles, plus déprimées qu'hier, les valeurs n'ont donné lieu qu'à de rares transactions, sans importance. Nous voulons croire encore qu'une allure aussi déplorable est un effet de la fête israëlite qui vient d'avoir lieu.

Pour juger de l'état de dépression auquel nous sommes parvenu, il nous suffira de relater l'enchère qui a eu lieu : 100 Estates à 21/32 et 50 Delta Light à 9 9/16. Jusques-là rien que de normal. Mais les 25 Anglo-American Nile ont été mises à prix à 1 livre et adjugées finalement à 2 livres !
Un titre qui est à l'ordre du jour de la fai-blesse, si l'on peut s'exprimer ainsi, c'est l'Ur-baine qui vient d'être ramenée en quelques séances de 3 1/2 à 3 3/16 et aujourd'hui enfin à 3 livres.
En baisse également les Jouissances Eaux du Caire de 203 à 202, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien de 300 à 299 l'ancienne et de 254 à -253 vendeurs la nouvelle.
L'Auto-Transport, qui était montée ces jours derniers de 4 à 4 1/4, après un long délaissement à 4, vient de s'effondrer d'un seul conp à 3 3/4, soit-en perte d'une demilivre.

La Delta Light est réelleme t la seule valeur dirigeante qui ait haussé ce matin de 9 1/2 acheteur à 9 9 16 sec. Quant à l'Agricole et à | la National Bank, leurs cours respectifs sont de 8 1/16 vendeurs et 20 1/8 vendeurs au lieu de 8 acheteurs et 20 3/32 acheteurs la veille, c'est-à-dire bonnet blanc au lieu de blanc bonnet.

Parmi les titres de moindre envergure, la Delta Land se consolide à 1 3/4 acheteurs et l'Investment à 1/2 acheteurs ; les Estates s'avancent de 5/8 nominal à 21/32 à la suite l'une demande, ainsi que le Comptoir de 2 1/8 à 2 1/4 l'ancienne action, de 2 3/16 à 2 5/16 la nouvelle et de 2 à 2 1/8 la part de fondateur; les Ritz progressent aussi de 1/2 à 17/32; en revanche, la Building Lands fléchit de 2 1/16 à 2 et la Cassa di Sconto de 38 à 37; on offre l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail à 21/-
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changements à signaler.
Sur les march's européens les prix des valenrs égyptiennes n'ont pas varié; seule la National Bank a reperdu à 20 1/4 l'avance de 1/8 qu'elle avait gagné hier.

Le taux privé d'escompte en Angleterre reste à 40.0, ce qui permettra sans doute à la Banque d'Angleterre, qui maintient le sien à 4 1/2, d'augmenter considérablement sa réserve, qni se trouve légèrement inférieure à ce qn'elle était l'année passée à pareille époque.

Bref, la situation financière générale ne s'est pas sensiblement modifiée, comme on peut s'en assurer par la lecture des informations que nous publions d'autre part aujourd'hui même. Le seul fait nouveau à constater c'est comme nous l'avons déjà dit, l'inquiétante raréfaction des échanges, tant sur les places dirigeantes qu'en Egypte. Ceci semble indiquer que, sans que la crise ait augmenté d'intensité, il s'est produit un certain tassement à la suite. des nombreux achats occasionnés par la récente débâcle. Il n'y 2 donc pas lieu de se préocouper outre mesure du marasme actuel.

div.head: WORK DURING 1906
div.p: The Statistical Department, under the directorship of Monsieur Randone, is temporarily attached to the Survey Department, and a brief account of the work done by the statistical staff is given in Captain Lyon's report on the latter.

In the course of the month of July, a first volume on the statistics of the Suez Canal for the year 1905 appeared. It contained a com-parative study of the ships belonging to the different nationalities which have passed through the Canal since it was first opened.

The statistics of the navigation in the ports of Egypt were also systematically published. The four first bulletins have already buen published, completing the twelve months of 1906. The port offices and the quarantine offices of the ports have rendered the greatest: assistance in furnishing the necessary informa-tion. By means of postcards, much additional information on the same subject. has been obtained from the agents of the different lines of shipping and it has been included in the three monthly publications.

The study of educational statistics has also been pushed forward, and in the month of November it was found possible to publish a provisional list of the schools in Egypt. To these schools were distributed lists of questions which were readily answered, and a large amount of material is now available which is being prepared for publication.

A beginning has been made to systematise, to some extent, the statistical information obtainable about the companies and societies which are established in Egypt. Many of them have already supplied much information of value, and it will doubtless be possible shortly to publish the results of this investigation.

The production of a Statistical Year Book of Egypt has hitherto been found extremely difficult owing to the very unequal quality of the statistics available. A large amount of these have, however, by this time been examined, and it is hoped that a Year Book will be published next year which will give all such statistical information as is sufficiently reliable while the material which can be less depended upon may be included in so far as it may be of comparative utility, having regard to its accuracy being only approximate.

div.head: THE SUDAN.
div.p: Much as our contemporary the "Egyptian Standard” has amused us by its discoveries, we have seldom seen so laughable a version of geography and current events as that which appears in yesterday's copy of Mustapha Kamel's organ. A correspondent at Cairo who has visited the War Office to enquire into the truth of the "Egyptian Standard's" information, and has studied the map of Africa for five minutes, a precaution, the adoption of which we recommend to the editors of the "Egyptian Standard's" ere they again venture to discuss the politics of the Upper Nile, writes to us as follows :—

"Like the fabled German, who evolved a camel out of his inner consciousness, the fire eating Mr. Rudy or the patriotic Mr. Maloney have imagined a new Sudan, I might almost say a new Africa. The independent regions of the Bahr el Ghazal are non-existent. The whole of that region after its conquest by Ismail Pasha, its loss to the Dervishes, became by right of conquest and treaties with its chiets, a part of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and marches with the territories known as the Congo Free State and the French Congo. Tambura who is described as the Sultan of the Niam Niams, and whom the editors of the "Egyptian Standard” doubtless regard as a noble savage rightly struggling to be free, is the chief of one of the sections of the Niam Niams tribe, who have no supreme head and hasalways accepted the existing Sudan Government. This people under various chiefs inhabits districts in the south Bahr el Ghazal, in French Congo, and in Belgian territory, and was formerly addicted to cannibalism and slave raiding. Dar For is not independent but ruled by a Sultan, Ali Dinar by name, who pays a yearly tribute to the Sudanese Government, which gave its consent to his nomination as Sultan after the battle of Omdurman. Dar Fur, Egyptian by right of conquest after the overthrow of its ruler at Menowashi by the famous Zubehr Pasha, was temporarily lost during the Dervish rebellion, and on the reconquest of the Sudan: by Lord Kitchener reverted to Egypt, this time associated with the British Empire. As for the ‘martyrs' recklessly sent towards Bahr el Ghazal and Dar Fur! Heavens ! one might as well say that a policeman killed accidently on his beat at Rugby by a motor or a run away horse had been recklessly sent towards "Land's End or John O'Groat's." Bat just as some serpents must cover with slime the bodies of the victims they devour, so onr contemporary must add to the pain of the kinsmen of the unfortunate victims of the Bir Natrûn disaster, by describing their fate as more horrible than it really was, for though death by. thirst is terrible, death by "buriyng alive” has always inspired a peculiar terror, and by insinuating that they were the victims of official recklessness, when their loss was undonbtedly due to the mistake of a guide who paid for his error with his life. And, it insinuations of this sort unsupported by proof are necessary, in the in, terests of Egyptian nationalism, is it really: obligatory on the editors of the Egyptian Standard” to falsify history and geography ? Will they accept a copy of the "Times” Atlas ? or is it suspect ?

div.head: COIN COLLECTORS IN EGYPT.
div.p: ANCIENT COINS OF GREECE

Owing to the wandering propensities of the ancient Greeks who, like the Scotch, were apparently never so much at home as when they were abroad, and also to the special attractions which the great empire of Egypt had for the Hellenic merchants and travellers, there is no place where a more varied selection of Greek coins can be made than in the land of Egypt.

For this reason the publication of an excellent description of ancient Greek coins at so reasonable a price as to be easily within the reach of any resident or visitor to Egypt likely to be a collector, is worthy of notice. Such a book is "Common Greek Coins” by the Revd. A. W. Hands just pablished by Messrs. Spink and Son of Picadilly, London.

The possessor of this work would be able to take a scientific historical interest in the many Greek coins to be obtained in the shops and bazaars, or from the village fellahs in Egypt and if he closely studies all that Mr. Hands tells about Greek numismatics would obtain a very complete knowledge of a most fascinating subject.

The book, as the preface states, is written for beginners, who can afford only to collect common coins ; but it will enable readers to detect also those which are more valuable, and a collector of very small means for the hobby can by wise use of it acquire occasionally specimens which can be disposed of at sufficient profit to pay for the accumulation of a very large cabinet of the more common varieties, As is well known, the old Greek coins teach much as to the religion and political history of their cities and states, their rise and fall, the legends of the heroes ; and the gradual growth of art and especially of sculpture can be studied from coing. So also may the rise and duration of cults and worships, by the favour in which such deities as Zeus and Apollo, Aphrodite or Athene, Heracles and others are graven upon the money from period to period.

The first volume of "Common Greek Coins" reviews those of Athens, Corinth, Aeginagathe Boeotian League, Alexander the Great and the Lycian League. Of these perhaps more specimens of the types of Alexander's coins turn up in Egypt than those of any of the others, and Mr. Hands provides six photogravures of the silver coins of the great Greek conqueror. Coins of the type of Alexander, but issued after his death, are very numerons. Plutarch tells that there were 70 cities named after Alexander, and many of these for long periods minted coins imitating those of their founder.

Because of the popularity of his coins for mercantile transactions, all over the then known world, numerous other towns also copied the coins, but to distinguish the mintage engraved the initials of the city upon them, and a list of these is given. About half of them also placed in the reverse of the coin the crest or symbol of their city, such as the Bee of Ephesus and the Bull of Antioch. The chapter upon the coins of Athens is specially full and adequately illustrated, and as its monies were for a long period used in trade all over the eastern Mediterranean more than any others, deservedly fully considered.

It must not be thought that "Common Greek Coins" is merely a catalogue of ancient Greek money, for it is far more than this. The de scribing of the coins is utilised to give a cleverly condensed, but most interesting, account of Greek history and mythology, commerce and progress in civilisation. The colonies and conquests of the Hellenes, their foolish feuds and transient friendships all come under survey and comment, and the usually erudite style of Greek numismatists is transformed into a brilliant and most readable essay upon the ancient Greek, world. This first volume is provided with a useful index, and catalognes of the monograms, initials, symbols and various mint marks are duly set forth to the various chapters, assisted by numerous engravings of all the more important types.
JOSEPH OFFORD
* "Common Greek Coins" Vol : 1 by the Reyd A. W. Hands, Pollow of the Royal Numismatic Society London. Spink and Son, 17 Piccadilly, 178 pages price 5/-.

div.head: THE "OLIVEMOOR".
div.p: As reported in our issue of yesterday the salvage steamer "Berger Wilhelm" went out to the "Olivemoor", but returned in the after: noon, having found that the weather was toorought to allow the salvage steamer to approach the wreck. This morning, however, the weather has been more favourable and the "Berger Wilhelm" again left harbour shortly after daybreak, and has now commenced pumping. Referring toonr paragraph of the day before yesterday concerning the trunks of patterns. valued at £5,000, it has been pointed out to us that such was not the intrinsic value of the material, but the figure which the consignee might hope to obtain through their medium. We are confident that this would be quite apparent to all our readers, samples in them: selves usually being considered as of no commercial value.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA v. CAIRO.
div.p: Having played a drawn match with Cairo on Saturday, teams representing the same, towns tried conclusions at golf and lawn tennis at the Sporting Club on Sunday :—
GOLF.

The visitors proved too good for the homesters at the "Royal and Ancient Game" and won by 4 points to 2. Alexandria, in each case where they lost the match, won the bye. The result of the matches were as follows: —

In the premier match some very fine play was seen, Morice being 3 up on his opponent at the 12th hole ; Wigham then won the remaining 5 holes and the match by 2 up and 1 to play. Morice had the misfortune to be laid stymies three holes in succession, Burnham proved in inresistable form, and giving Clarke no opportunity beat him by 4 and 2. Scott made Dalgeish go all the way to win, which he did principally through his strong green play, which was his opponents weak spot, although he holed a fine 20 foot put on the 18th green.

Boys must be considered lucky in finding Mainprice right off his game and playing strongly himself won handsomely by 5 and 3. Barnard in his match with Etherington Smith won the only match for Alexandria ; losing his ball at the first hole he was 1 down at the 3rd, but was never down again and, playing steadily, won by 2 up.
LAWN TENNIS.

Alexandria avenged their defeat of the morning at tennis in the afternoon by winning, 8 sets to 1. The matches were watched with interest by a number of spectators who appreciated the high standard of the play.

row.cell: G. Scott Daleigh and H. Boys.
lost to D. G. Morice and H. B. Carver 5-7, 1-6
lost to T. H. Marsden and R. L. Barnard 6-2, 3-6, 3-6
H. R. Brereton and H.S. Job.
lost to D. G. Morice and H. B. Carver 4-6, 5-7
lost to T. H. Marsden and R. L. Barnard 5-7, 1-6

div.p: The home team as will be seen by the score proved too good for Cairo. Morice and Carver played splendidly together, their service line, game being, very strong, Marsden displayed all his old skill and reliability on the base line, whilst Barnard's good work at the net made them an effective couple. The visitors were naturally handicapped by playing on strange courts, but nevertheless gave a good display.

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: 2nd BATTALION ROYAL INNISKILLING FUSILIERS.
B. COMPANY v. F. COMPANY.

The above two well-known teams met at Kasr-el-Nil recreation grounds in the opening matoh, of the season. The ground was in the pink of condition. The teams were as follows. BCoy,goal, Cowan, hacks, Walker, and Longbrien balves MoClean, Irwin and, Magee forwards Smithe-Smith, Heathwood, Brady, and Conngol ghon, F Company goal Pritchard, backs Brazil and Lyons, halves Collins, Godfrey and Hillyer, forwards Kenny, Bradshaw, Lowe Langford, and Armstrong.
THE GAME.

F Company won the spin of the coin, and Heathwood commenced operations by kicking off- for the blues before 500 spectators. The blues at once got away, the ball finding touch. Play was confined to inidfield for a short period until Heathwood got possession and dodging two opponents passed to Brady, who was robbed by Collins. Kenny and Bradshaw were playing well together and proved-themselves too quick for Magee. Longhrie averted disaster when the stripes seemed like scoring, and midfield play followed. F Company now took play in hand. Walker took the ball from the toe of Armstrong, as the latter was in the act of shooting. The pressure was relieved only for a moment as the stripes came again and Cowan got a few stiff shots to deal with, which he saved in splendid style. The blues now took play in hand, bnt Brady spoiled a good op portunity by over eagerness. The blues had several chances to score but overengerness. spoiled all attempts. The stripes. were quioker on the ball and Cowan-was tested several times. But all to no avail as he was simply unbeatable. It was a lucky thing for the blaes that Cowan was in international form, or a goal would have been certain ; he had to acknowledge defeat, however, by a long shot from Armstrong. Play now took a turn towards the stripes citadel, where Heathwood ended up a pretty bout of passing by sending past the ball that much desired spot. The stripes by good play got close to Cowan, and Bradshaw sending past the same player shortly after all but scored, Cowan bringing off meat save for which he was cheered. Play was in midheld when half time was announced with the score reading
F. Company . . . 1 goal.
B. Company . . . Nil.
SECOND HALF.

The second half was resgmed by Lowe. The blues front rank were seen to advantage, Smythe sending past when nicely placed. Brady and Connaghon were combining well but their footwork was a trifle slow. The stripes had several chances to score but Loughrie bested Kenny every time. F. Company's front rank were going strong when an off-side pulled them up and from the a following free the blues pressed, Connaghou shoved the upright with a daisy. Play for a while remained in the stripes and the blues could not score, the ball being planted everywhere except in the proper place. Play now went in favour of the stripes Cowan was tested twice in succession but Robert came through the order with flying colours. F. Company were having slightly the best of a good game and only for Cowan's brilliant work between the sticks goals were certain. Good footwork by Heathwood resulted in Connaghon sending past. From the kick off Heatwood once more got possession and dedging. Lyons he sent a long shot in to Pritchard who saved well. The stripes now took play in hand and Langford who seemed offside headed past Cowan, the latter making a praiseworthy attempt to save. Not disheartened by this reverse the blues got close to Lyons and company. Collins in saving conceded a corner which proved unproductive. Good headwork by Walker let his front rank away. Hillyer however robbed Smith, and play was transferred towards Cowan who savd well from Armstrong and Lowe. Play was in the blues camp, when the referee sounded his whistle for full time, the final score being
F. Company . . . 2 goals.
B. Company . . . Nil.
Mr. Lyons refereed to the satisfaction of all concerned.

div.head: THE LATE REV. THORNTON.
div.p: As announced by us on Monday the death of the Reverend Douglas M. Thornton, M.A, took place at the Cairo Nursing Home at 4,30 a m. on Sunday morning last, following typhoid fever. A native of Norfolk, he gra-duated at Cambridge with honours, in, math-matics where he was closely identified with the Christian Movement in connection, with the Universities of Britain. In the work of Foreign Missions he was deeply read, even before his appointment to the Mission field and when entering upon such in Egypt in 1898 as Mis-sioner to the Mohamedans, in the service of the Church Missionary Society, he had an unusual advantage of the subjects and was a fluent Arabic scholar. His genial and kindly manner soon won the hearts of those to whom he preached and could without difficulty hold an andience of Egyptians for upwards of two hours as was the case when on a preaching tour in Upper Egypt, a tour which he had an-ticipated with pleasure, which was realized shortly prior to his death. His guiding in-fluence over young men in Egypt was consi-derable while he contributed, as few have done, in a practical way, to cementing friendship between the Anglican and Coptic communities. His achievements in the service of his Master is a record for a life closing at the age of 34 into which short span he compressed a great amount of work and overtaxed his strength which was indirectly accountable for his death. The funeral took place on Sunday after-noon at the New Cemetry.

The Reverend Thompson Burns M. A. Chaplain of All Saints made pulpit reference at evensong on Sunday in the course of which he said "Today a life has passed away. I refer to the death of the Rev. Douglas Thornton. A man of exceptional ability who had spent himself in endeavonring to cast out the evil that is marring the lives of so many in this country. He had saized upon that which is of value for the eternal life to come ; thus, while we pray that God may comfort those sorrowing for his loss, we also bless His Holy Name for the example, which through the help of God he has set, of a faithful and earnest servant of Christ." At the conclusion of the service the organist played, "O Best in the Lord.
The flag of St. Mark's Church, Alexandria, was hung at half mast on Sunday.

div.head: INFORMATIONS FINANCIERES
div.p: LA SITUATION DE L'ABOUKIR C°.
(D'un correspondant)

La concession originelle du Gouvernement égyptien portait sur environ 80,000 feddans dont 19,250 ont été vendus pour £559,780, partie en espèces, partie en paiements échelonnés, dont £130,000 restent à toucher.

Il reste ainsi environ 10,700 feddans et la Compagnie a l'intention de loner ces terrains et de payer les dividendes sur ce revenu plutôt que de persister à les vendre. On peut prévoir qa'à la fin de 1908 la totalité des terrains seront en passe d'être mis en location.

La Compagnie possède en outre un intérêt, dans la proportion de deux tiers, dans une autre propriété de 1,577 feddans, entièrement canališde et partiellement louée à raison de £5 par feddan. C'est donc un total de 11,700 fed. daris, dont le bail moyen, calculé à £4 10s par fèddan, produirait un revenu brut de £52,650 permettant à la Compagnie de payer de bons dividendes, toutes charges déduites.
La position financière est très forte, £80,000 en espèces outre les £130,00 à recevoir sur les ventes déjà effectuées.

Le prix moyen par feddan obtenu en 1906 a été £76 sur lequel les achetears ont réalisé un bénéfico considérable. Tout dernièrement la Cumpagnie a vendu 23 feddans à £120, mais en prenant pour base d'évalnation £40 par feddan seulement, les
soit tout près de £2 par action de £1.
Les actions sont cotées officiellement. Il vient d'être distribué pour le semestre au 30 Juin, un dividende de 4% soit sur la base de 8% l'an.

div.head: BUILDING LANDS OF EGYPT
div.p: C'est le jeudi 19 courant, que se tiendra à Alexandrie l'assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires de la Building Lands of Egypt afip de ratifier les décisions suivantes prişes à titre provisoire par l'assemblée générale extra ordinaire du 17 aont 1907 :

a) Autorisation au Conseil de réduire le capital social, aux termes de l'article 7 des statnts, à concurrence d'une somme de £50,868, par le rachat au-dessous du pajr de 12,717 actions, lesquelles devront être annalées et remplacées aux termes des articles 16 et 40, par des actions de jouissance qui seront réparties entre les actionnaires lorsque le rachat aura été complété.
b) Autorisation au Conseil d'employer à ce rachat: 1. le montant de la réserve; 2. les bénéfices de l'exercice 1906 reportés à nouveau; 3. les bénéfices devant résulter des achats effectués.
c) Pouvoir au Conseil à l'effet d'émettre des obligations si le besoin s'en fait sentir.
L'assemblée aura ensuite à modifier l'article 7 comme suit :

"Le capital peut être réduit par échange : des actions anciennes contre des titres nonveaux de valeur différente ou par toute autre voie et ce en vertu d'une décision de l'assemblée générale sur la proposition du Conseil d'administration.

"Dans le cas de réduction du capital par voie de rachat au-dessous du pair, le Conseil devra créer les actions de jouissance prévues à l'article 16 et les distribuer au prorata entre les actionnaires de la Société."

div.head: SITUATION MONETAIRE GENERALE
div.p: Pour faire suite aux appréciations que nous avons émises au sujet de la situation monétaire générale et dans le but de les appuyer, nous nous empressons de reproduire les passages suivants d'un article remarquable paru dans Anvers Bourse :

"... Pour le moment les grands centres financiers ne se trouvent pas dans des positions très brillantos ; néanmoins, l'avenir ne leur inspire pas de trop grandes craintes. L'Angletorre prévoit que sa banque centrale pourra disposer d'un montant considérable de métal jaune avant la fin de l'année. La France est parvenue à renforcer les positions de sa première institution de crédit, avant que les difficultés monétaires de l'automne ne l'aient assaillie.

Même l'Amérique, où la mobilisation des récoltes cause toujours une grande demande de moyens d'échange, semble envisager l'avenir calme. Il est vrai que l'Europe a constamment refusé au nouveau monde le crédit dont celui-ci disposait régulièrement chaque année. Mais d'autre part, le secrétaire du trésor a promis de venir en aide au marché d'une façon efficace. Cette promesse, émanant de M. Cortelyon a d'autant plus d'importance que celuici a décidé de remédier au mal tout de suite et avant que les besoins de la place n'aient complètement épuisé les disponibilités.

"... En ce qui concerne des autres pays, tels que l'Allemagne et l'Autriche-Hongrie, ils se tiennent sur l'expectative et tâchent de préserver lear stock métallique, déjà pas trop considérable, au moyen d'un taux d'escompte élevé.
"D'ailleurs, au point de vue du marché moitetaire international, ce sont surtout Londres et New-York qui, maintenant plus que jamais, dirigeront les destinées du monde."

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi sous la présidence de S.E. Schiess Pacha.

L'ingénieur en chef ayant proposé l'achat d'une pompe à vapeur pour l'arrosage des routes des quais, la Délégation, tout en approuvant cette acquisition, décide de la renvoyer au printemps prochain. Le coût sera de 200 livres.

Le nouvel emplacement pour la construction des latrines à Kom el Nadoura présentant des inconvénients, la Délégation a décidé sur la proposition de l'ingénieur en chef de les construire dans un autre emplacement à Sahed Bakir, après avis favorable de l'inspecteur sanitaire.

Au sujet du transport de la caillasse des bords do Canal Mahmondieb, où elle encombre la route, la Délégation, sur la proposition de l'ingénieur en chef, a décidé d'établir une voie Decauville, pour la transporter aussitôt après son débarquement, directement aux dépôts. A cet effet, la Délégation a décidé de mettre en adjudication l'installation de cette voie Decauville.
Elle adjuge à M. Ramadan Youssef la construction de quatre chalets de nécessité dans différents quartiers de la ville, raison de 381 Livres,

Elle a pris connaissance d'une demande de M. Spiro Seouli, pour l'établissement sur la Place Mohamed Aly d'un salon de décrottage. La Délégation regrette de rejeter cette démande, la Municipalité ne pouvant pas louer le sol public. M. Seooli peut toutefois louer un magasin où bon lui semblera pour en faire un salon de déerottage, comme il en existe au Caire.
La Délégation a appronvé la vente d'immondices à une Société, à condition que ces immondices soient transportées hors de la ville dans le plus bref délai.
Elle a décidé la suppression des échèches près des bains Nasri, par mesure sanitaire et de procéder an nettoiement de celles qui sont près des prisons de Gabbari.
Elle a renvoyé aux services techniques pour rapport les offres faites par MM. P. A. Gerakis et Loria, séparément, pour la construction de la nouvelle route sur les nouveanx quais allant à Ras-el-Tin.

Elle a pris connaissance des recettes de la Municipalité qui s'élèvent du 1er Janvier au 31 Août à L.E. 173,867 et des dépenses L.E. 135,284, pour le budget ordinaire. Pour le budget extraordinaire, les recettes s'élèvent à L.E. 99,637 sur lesquels L E. 93,036, reliquat de l'année dernière, sont déjà engagées.
La séance a été levée à 7 h. 30 p m.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust-ive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
div.p: THE COAST QUIET.
The situation is calm on the Moorish coast.
(Havas)
The advance has been postponed owing to General Drude's indisposition. The General is suffering from fever.
(Reuter)

Replying to the notification of the intention on the part of France and Spain to establish a temporary European police forces with a view to facilitating the eventual establishment of Moorish police, according to the Algeciras Convention, Germany assumes that the mea· sures taken, are only temporary. She has already acknowledged the right of France to satisfaction and does not want to place difficulties to her way; she hopes however that damages to foreign merchants will not be repeated, and for that season points out to her Chargé d'Affaires at Tangier that she fears the establishment of a foreign police force will provoke attacks by the mountain tribes on the seaports, with consequent danger to foreigners unless it is backed up by an adequate military force.
(Reuter)

div.head: FIGHTING AT CUAMANHAS.
div.p: WHITES LOSE HEAVILY.
LISBON, September 10.

According to a telegram received from laonda several engagements have been fought within the last few days at Cuamanhas : 19 white and 4 native soldiers have been killed, and 5 officers, 53 white, and 39 native soldiers wounded.
(Reuter)

div.head: STEERABLE BALLOON TRIALS.
div.p: SATISFACTORY RESULTS.
LONDON, September 10.

The steerable military balloon has made its first ascent at Aldershot. It turned repeatedly in its own length and completed a 5 mile semicircle in half an hour in a steady breeze. The driving belt then snapped and the balloon descended and was towed home. The officials are delighted with the result of the trial.
(Reuter)

div.head: RUSSO-JAPANESE CONVENTION.
div.p: EXCHANGE OF RATIFICATIONS.
ST. PETERSBURG, September 10.
The ratifications of the Russo-Japanese conventions were exchanged at Tokio to-day.
(Reuter)

div.head: SIR R. SLATIN PASHA.
div.p: GAZETTED MAJOR GENERAL.
LONDON, September 10.
Slatin Pasha has been gazetted an honorary Major Cieneral of the British Army. (Reuter)

div.head: A PEACE MAKING TOUR.
div.p: The ex-Prime Minister, M. Ralli, is starting on a tour in Rumelia in order to persuade the Greeks to cultivate peaceful relations with people of other nationalities and not to hinder reforms.
(Reuter)

div.head: SIGNOR MALMUSI'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: Mr. Malmusi, Minister at Cairo, has been asked to resign. It is said in political circles that this decision was caused by his indecisive attitude in regard to the Sultan of Morocco, when he went to submit to him the Algeciras Act.
(Reuter)
THE TRAGEDY OF EMPIRE.
HISTORY'S WARNING TO THE BRITISH PEOPLE.
BY A SOLDIER.

There have for a long time been voices crying in the wilderness, with solemn but unheeded warnings, to the British people of the coming of a day of national test and trial which shall decide their worthiness to retain the Imperial heritage of their fathers. But none has advanced in plainer and more convincing terms the lesson of national failure in the Empires of the past than Mr. Ellis Barker in his lecture last February at the Royal United Service Institution.

Unfortunately such utterances always fail to reach the ears of any but those who are already assured of our national shortcomings and the people at large remain ignorant and unconvinced that they are fast drifting towards the doom of all great Empires before them. As Mr. Barker demonstrated, history conclusively proves how nations always remained great and powerful so long as they accepted the principle of self-denial involved in the maintenance of national armies composed of the best manhood of the people, while their decline and fall have invariably dated from the disinclination of the national manhood to sustain the burden of military service, and the consequent employment of paid or mercenary soldiers.

Egypt comes first in the long line of disaster. We see her at an early date a powerful and very wealthy State, with a national army of 400,000 men. It was an army composed of landholders and men of a well-to-do caste, for in those days, as Diodorus Siculus tells us, Egypt regarded it as unsafe to leave the defence of the country to those who had no material stake in its preservation. As long as she was defended by this army, composed of| the national manhood, she retained her magnificence, her wealth and power. But in the seventh century B.C., under Psammeticus, this national army was superseded by one of paid soldiers, chiefly Greeks from Ionia and Caria, and Egypt rapidly declined. Attacked by another natimpal army, that of the Persians, then a hardy race of mountaineers, her greatness and glory departed for ever in the disastrous overthrow at Pelusium in 525 B.C. Since then she has been ruled by foreigners.

Then the Persians, having possessed themselves of the wealth of Egypt and the Near East, waxed exceeding rich and prosperous. Their ancient discipline was relaxed, and the process of decadence was at once evinced by their abandonment of a national army. Xenophon records that they now recruited their military forces from the lowest of the people and by levies from subject races. Consequently, in the army with which Xerxes attacked Greece the national manhood of Persia was scarcely represented at all, and its destruction by the truly national forces of the Greeks was the natural result.

When Greece achieved this great triumph her armies were national in every sense of the word. The Greek citizen regarded it as an honour and a privilege to bear arms in defence of his country, and high and low, rich and pour, fought side by side in the national cause. But Greece, in her tun, became corrupted and en rvated by wealth and luxury, till, only a houdred years after the triumph of Salamis, we find the orator Isocrates lamenting the substitution of hireling soldiers for the national
warriors of the former days "Formerly," he says, "mercenaries were unknown to us, but now our position is such that it is får easier to raise an army of vagabonds than a citizen army."

But the Greeks believed that their wealth would provide them with adequate means of | defence, and turned a deaf ear to the Robertses of their day. So when at last Philip II. of Macedon fell upon them with his national army they were hopelessly overthrown at Chæronea, in spite of the self devoting bravery of the Sacred Band of Thebes, whom we may aptly regard as the half-trained, half-disciplined volunteers of the time. So the Greeks became, like the Egyptians and Persians before them, a subject race, the prey in turn of Macedoniang, Romans, Goths, Byzantines, and Turks.

Mr. Barker next pointed us to Phoenicia as the greatest maritime and colonial Power of antiquity, but one which relied chiefly apon her naval power and shirked citizen service in. her land forces, recruiting these from subject races and her oversea colonies. As an inevit able result she was despoiled of her wealth and power, and when in the hour of her, ex. tremity her citizens woke up and formed themselves into volunteer forces their desperate, but untrained, efforts availed nothing against their trained and disciplined enemies.

And what of Carthage? She mightily increased in wealth and power. She could boast of a great fleet, enormous land forces, and skilled leader. But she fell before the far less wealthy power of Rome, and Polybius, the historian of the Panic wars, tells us that it was because "Carthaginians employed mercenary soldiers, while Rome fought with a national army."

But now it was the turn of Rome. So weighty and powerful had she become that as she gazed around on a subject world she might be excused for believing her position to be un. challengeable. What need any longer, said her citizens, of a national army? We will hire the poor man to do the work for us. And so, the historian says, "The security of a long peace altered the disposition of the Romans, drew them from military to civil vocations, and created in them a love of ease and idleness. Military discipline, after having been neglected, disappeared entirely." Tacitus tells us how the old sound principles of universal compulsory service fell into abeyance; the Roman soldier was recruited from the starving and out-of-work classes of the big towns, or from subject races. What the result was we know.

Through all it is the same old sad story. The Empire of the East, based upon Constantinople, held out for a time, but this, too, relied upon a voluntarily enlisted army, recruited from the lower classes, and in its turn fell before the national armies of the Turks.

We now reach the zenith of Spanish power in the sixteenth century. There was none to compare with Spain on land or sea. But her armies were not national armies, and eventually they went down before the national armies of the revolted Netherlanders: In her turn, for a time, Holland, succeeding to the riches and oversea possessions of Spain, enjoyed great wealth and power. But relying wholly upon their fleets, her citizens shirked the obligation of military service, leaving it to the poorer classes of the population, and when attacked by Louis XIV, were overrun in the short space of forty days, and their world power fell to pieces.

Take, again, that period of modern history which has witnessed the development of national from non-national armies. Prussia fell at Jena because she ignored the solemn warnings of Scharnhorst, and other patriots of the type of Lord Roberts, and persisted in relying upon & non national Army to withstand the national armies of France. But after that terrible defeat she instituted universal military service and the power of united Germany today continues to be based upon that of the national army. On the other hand France, wearied by the great Napoleon's endless wars, denationalised hers—that is to say, the better classes and those who could afford it were enabled to escape service by the purchase of substitutes, and, in consequence, the army was filled with the poorest, most ignorant, and least healthy of the people. It was this army which tell before the more numerous and better organized national armies of Germany in 1870-71. Roused by this terrible lesson, France again reformed her army, and now possesses one based on universal military service.

Looking critically at the recent struggle for South Africa, there is very little doubt that had the Boers possessed a national arny instead of merely a national militia, which was entirely without the organization, discipline, training, and cohesion of the former, the whole country from the Cape to the Zambesi would have been lost to Great Britain. As it was, our non-national forces required a prolonged breathing space, and even then only triumphed with tremendous difficulty.

The reason for the triumph of the national over non-national armies in the past has always been due to the possession by the former of superior moral, intelligence, physique, and numerical force, and the opinion of every competent authority, ancient or modern, agrees in this, while events confirm it from the day of Peluslum to Sedan. Therefore, ag Great Britain can enjoy no exemption from this law. it is very certain that in a struggle for existence against great national forces her nonnational army will stand no better chance against the national forces of her enemies than did the paid regulars of Carthage, with their untrained masses behind them.

Already our record is black enough through our lack of a national army. For this would undoubtedly have preserved to us our American Colonies, and saved £200,000,000, the cost of the war. It would effectually have hindered

Napoleon from devastating Europe for twenty terrible years, thus saying millions of lives and £1,000,000,000 to this country; and it is equally certain that the Boers would never have ventured on war had our forces been organized on this national basis. ..)

What is the conclusion of the whole matter? It is not suggested that there were no other causes than the one we are considering which contributed to the fall of the powerful Empires of the past. Nevertheless, it is very certain that the abandonment of national armies has always been one of the earliest visible effects of national decadence, and nearly all these oldworld Empires succumbed generally after a single blow, because their manhood had shrunk from national military service and preferred to entrust their interests to a hired soldiery.

As Mr. Barker justly observed, non-national armies have achieved splendid successes under such leaders as Hannibal, Marlborough, and Wellington. But such leaders were exceptional geniuses, and even they required time to knock their material into shape, time which will never be obtainable amidst, the lightning development of modern warfare.

Whether the last and largest Empire on the world's stage is preparing in its tarn for decay or yet further development must depend upon the resolution of its people. Alone among the armed nations, its rivals, it clings to a selfindulgent form of military service, and shirks the defence of its Empire by a national army. The story of Egypt, of Persia, of Carthage, and of Rome, as well as every modern example, are eloquent with warning of the inevitable result of this abnegation of national responsibility, and Great Britain will not be able to escape the operation of the same remorseless law.
"Pall Mall Gazette”

div.p: NOTICE is hereby given that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above-named Company will be held at the Company's Of-fices, Alexandria Central Buildings, on Wednesday, the 25th day of September 1907 at 5 o' clock in the afternoon to confirm the resolution passed at the Extraordinary General Meeting held on the 10th Sept. instant.
"That Article 87 of the Articles of Association of the Company be and is hereby rescinded and that in lieu thereof the following Article shall be substituted, that is to say:

(87) – From and after the first day of January 1908 the qualification of a Director shall be the holding of at least 500 shares in the capital of the Company. This Article shall not apply to an alternate Director appointed under Articles 91 hereof. Until such date it shall not be necessary for a Director to hold apy shares as a qualification.”
Alexandria, the 11th day of September 1907 Alex. Th. Kitroeff, Manager.

div.head: "Every One Thought I Had Consumption. Pe-ru-na Saved Me."
div.p: "I hardly know how to thank you for the good Perana has done me,

"I suffered five years with pain in the stomach. About a year ago it became so bad I could hardly bear it. I coughed day and night and grow weaker and weaker. The pain extended throngh my body and I also had difficulty in breathing, which made me cough Everyone thought I had consumption.
"My husband heard of Peruna and bought five bottles. This treatment vir-tually cured me and now I recommend Perang to every one who is suffering.
"I thank Dr. Hartman for this excellent remedy."
Ste. Julie de Vercheros, P.Q., Canada. —Mrs. Mois Parizean.
A NEGLECTED cold is generally the Pernas has been found the most first case of catarrh.

Women are especially liable to colds. These colds occur more frequently dur-ing the wet, sloppy weather of winter and spring than any other time of the year. Often they are not consid-ered serious and are allowed to run on, or they are treated in such a way as to only pallaste the symptoms, while the cold becomes more deep-seated and the patient finally awakens to the fact that she has a well-developed case of ca-tarrh.

By reason of their delicate structure, the lungs are frequently the seat of a cold, especially if there is the slightest weakness of these organs. The treatment of catarrh of the lungs is also more dif-ficult and discouraging than catarrh of any other organ of the body.
It would be wise therefore, to guard against it by every precaution possible.
Peruna has been found the most re-liable of all remedies for coughs, colds, and catarrh, by reason of the fact that it goes at once to the very seat of the trouble.

It searches out every crevice, every duct of the body. It quickens and equal-izes the circula-tion of the blood, thus relieving the congested mucous membranes. It exercises a healing and soothing effect upon the mucous membranes, no matter whether they are the more exposed membranes of the head and throat, or whether they line the remotest cells of the lungs.
Mrs. Jaschob, 1681 Hicks St.,, Toledo, Ohio, writes :

"When I wrote to you for advice, I had been sick for three years, I had trouble with my throat. Often I could not breathe through my nose. I also had pains in my chest and a cough. I took Peruns according to directions and it has cured me."
For special directions everyone would read "The Ills of Life," a copy, of which surrounds each bottle Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.

E. DEL MAR.

div.p: DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Le Supplement Commercial et Pinancier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de façon a pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autriobien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der-nières statistiques jusqu'a la veil:e de sa publi-cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour ape année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: THE STANDARD LIFE ASSURANCE CO.
div.p: ACCUMULATED FUNDS £11,750,000.
ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES with guaranteed bonus on survival of £2 per annum for each £100 of assurance.
CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENTS at low rates, with return of all premiums paid in the event of death before the given age is attained.

ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES WITH GUARANTEED BONUS ON SURVIVAL.—A, aged 30 next birthday, with Good prospect of longevity, takes out a Policy for £1,000 under this table for an Endowmont Assurance payable at the age of 60 or earlier death, with a Guaranteed Bonus of 40s. per cent per annum if he survives the fixed term, the annual premium for which will be £38:15:0. In the event of death within the 30 years, only the sum assured in the Policy is payable, viz : — £1,000, but if he survives the term, he is entitled to receive £1,000, a Guaranteed Bonus of 30 times 40s. per cent ; i.e. £600, or in all £1,600 ; and similarly for others periods and . Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired.

CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENTS.—An annual Premium of £18.1.8 will provide a child aged 1 next birthday with an Endowment of £500 on attaining the age of 21. In the event of the child's death before the given age is attained, all the premiums paid to the Company will be returned to the parent. Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired. Should the parent wish to discontinue the payment of premiums, he can claim a surrender value of 90 per cent of all the annual premiums paid by him, expecting the first, provided three full years premiums have been paid and the transaction is completed while the Policy is in force. Should the parent not wish to take the surrender value, he has the option, after three full years' premiums have been paid, of receiving a Paid-up Policy for such a propertion of the Original Sum Assured as the number of payments made bears to the whole number payable, if written application be made and the transaction completed within the days of grace, and provided such proportion be not less than £50.
For Prospectus, Forms of Proposal and all particulars, apply to the STANDARD LIFE OFFICE, STANDARD BUILDINGS, CAIRO. 30689-13-2
